{{italic title}} {{Use dmy dates|date=October 2010}} {{Unreferenced|date=December 2009}} The '''''Oxford-Hachette French to English/English to French Dictionary''''' is one of the most comprehensive and recent bilingual French–English/English–French dictionaries. It was the first such dictionary to be written using a computerized corpus and it contains 555,000 translations as well as 360,000 words and expressions. The work was first published in 1994, with its second, third and fourth editions appearing in 1997, 2001 and 2007 respectively. Though the dictionary is entirely bilingual, it is marketed under two different names, one for French, one for English:
*''Le grand dictionnaire Hachette-Oxford -French et anglais-français'' *''Oxford-Hachette French Dictionary: French-English English-French'' Its version is also available in a concise or condensed version. It is jointly published by [[Oxford University Press]] and [[Hachette (publishing)|Hachette Education]].
Its two main competitors are ''[[Harrap's Shorter French Dictionary]]'' published by [[Chambers Harrap|Chambers Harrap Publishers]] and ''[[Collins-Robert French Dictionary]]'' published by Harper-Collins. ==External links== *Oxford University Press: [http://www.oxfordreference.com/view/10.1093/acref/9780191739545.001.0001/acref-9780191739545 Pocket Oxford-Hachette French Dictionary: French-English (4 ed.)], [https://global.oup.com/academic/product/oxford-hachette-french-dictionary-9780198614227?cc=ca&lang=en& Oxford-Hachette French Dictionary Fourth Edition], [https://global.oup.com/academic/product/compact-oxford-hachette-french-dictionary-9780199663118?lang=en&cc=ca Compact Oxford-Hachette French Dictionary] *iTunes page: [https://itunes.apple.com/us/app/oxford-hachette-french-dictionary/id679624485?mt=8 Oxford-Hachette French Dictionary By MobiSystems, Inc.], [https://itunes.apple.com/us/app/oxford-hachette-french-dictionary/id1080647488?mt=8 Oxford-Hachette French Dictionary FREE By MobiSystems, Inc.] *Microsoft Store page: [https://www.microsoft.com/en-us/store/p/oxford-hachette-french-dictionary/9wzdncrdp7tb Oxford Hachette French Dictionary]
{{DEFAULTSORT:Oxford-Hachette French Dictionary: French-English English-French}} [[Category:1994 books]] [[Category:Oxford dictionaries]] [[Category:French dictionaries]] [[Category:English bilingual dictionaries]] [[Category:Hachette (publisher) books]]

{{infobox book | <!-- See [[Wikipedia:WikiProject Novels]] or [[Wikipedia:WikiProject Books]] --> | name = Schott's Almanac | image = SchottsLogo.png | caption = "A Book of the Past & A Song of the Future" | author = [[Ben Schott]] | cover_artist = Allison Lang <!-- | portrait_artist = [[Chris Lyon]] --> | country = [[United States]], [[United Kingdom]], [[Germany]] | language = [[English language|English]], [[German language|German]] | genre = [[Reference]] | published = 14 November 2005 [[Bloomsbury Publishing PLC]] | pages = 352 }}
'''''Schott's Almanac''''' was a best-selling UK reference book, published annually in the [[United Kingdom]] between 2006 and 2010. The book was compiled by [[Ben Schott]] and published by [[Bloomsbury Publishing Plc]].
In addition to the UK version, the best known (and oldest), two other editions of ''Schott's Almanac'' were published, in the United States and Germany. Each Almanac had a different content and structure, and the German edition was in German.
==The Almanac== The Almanac presented the world in thirteen† sections: *[[Chronicle]] ("''The events of the year, day by day...''") *[[World|The World]] ("''The four corners, the three worlds, the seven seas...''") *[[Society]] & [[Health]] ("''From cradle to grave, and everything in between...''") *[[Mass media|Media]] & [[Celebrity]] ("''From the Big Brother house to the craze of Sudoku...''") *[[Science|Sci]], [[Technology|Tech]], [[Internet|Net]] ("''The scientific and technological year dissected...''") *[[Music]] & [[Film|Cinema]] ("''Pop, classical, Hollywood, and art-house...''") *[[Books]] & [[Arts]] ("''Bestsellers, theatre, fashion, events, and exhibitions...''") *[[Travel]] & [[Leisure]] ("''Planes, trains, automobiles, and the rest...''"); *[[Money]] ("''Personal finance, from pay-day to Tax Freedom Day...''") *[[Parliament of the United Kingdom|Parliament]] & [[Politics]] ("''The facts and figures behind the spin...''") *[[Establishment of religion|Establishment]] and [[Faith]] ("''Royalty, nobility, military, and belief...''") *[[Sport]] ("''Sporting endeavour and achievement...''") *[[Ephemerides]] (''Key calendar dates and miscellany for the year ahead...'').
†In the US edition, this number was changed to a total of fifteen sections, with the addition of: *[[The United States of America|The Nation]] (''The state of the Union...'') *[[U.S. state|The States]] (''The state of the States...'') *[[U.S. Government|Government]] (''Donkey'' vs ''Elephant, Dove'' vs ''Hawk...'')
The aforementioned replace the UK edition's "Parliament" section. Other minor differences in the US edition include, but are not limited to, changing the UK's "The World" to "World & Gazetteer", "Music & Cinema" to "Music & Movies", "Establishment and Faith" to "Form & Faith", as well as rearranging the order of the chapters.
==External links== *{{official website|http://www.schottsalmanac.com/}} *[https://web.archive.org/web/20030810131314/http://www.miscellanies.info/ Schott's Miscellanies]

page.title: Second relation letter from Hernán Cortés to emperor Charles V

revision.comment: I fixed the chart to have the correct things in the correct columns.
revision.text:
{{Orphan|date=December 2015}} The '''Second relation letter from Hernán Cortés to emperor Charles V''' is one of the five ''Letters of relation'' written by [[Hernán Cortés]] to [[Charles V, Holy Roman Emperor]] by his name in the Holy Roman Empire, and to his mother, the queen [[Joanna of Castile]] in which he relates his trips to Mexico and the [[Spanish conquest of the Aztec Empire|conquest of Mexico-Tenochtitlán.]] This second letter was dated on 30 October 1520. == Content == [[File:4.-_50012_0003_-_Hernán_Cortés_-_Segunda_y_tercera_cartas_de_relación,_dirigidas_al_emperador_Carlos_V_1500-1558_done_narra_lo_ocurrido_entre_el_30_de_octubre_de_1520_hasta_el_15_de_mayo_de_1522.TIF|thumb|Hernán Cortés - Second and third letters of relation to the emperor Carlos V 1500-1558, where he narrates the events occurred between 30 October 1520 until 15 May 1522]] The letter begins with the headline:{{Cite book|title = Cartas de Relación|year = 2010|location = México|edition = 23|page = 37|last = Cortés|first = Hernán|publisher = Editorial Porrúa}} Written fifteen months after the ''First Letter'', Cortés informs in the ''Second letter of relation'' the previous process to the [[Spanish conquest of the Aztec Empire|conquest of Mexico-Tenochtitlán.]] It began with an apology to the kings for the time he took to write; and continued with the sinking of the brigs to avoid his men regret to go with him and go back to The Spaniard; he exposed his decision to conquer the city and with this justified his expedition. He described the power, wealth and religion of the [[Aztec|mexicas.]] He mentioned the meetings he had with the boss of [[Tlaxcala]], [[Xicotencatl II|Xicotencatl]] and the gold that received from the caciques and the [[tlatoani]] [[Moctezuma II]], his impressions when knowing the political conflicts within the territory and his visit with natives of [[Cholula (Mesoamerican site)|Cholula]]. Later he noted the conflicts with Moctezuma and his confrontation with mexicas, the battle that took place in Mexico-Tenochtitlán during his absence, when he left to meet with [[Pánfilo de Narváez|Pánfilo of Nárvaez]], the tlatoani's death and his defeat against mexicas forces. After this, they went to Tlaxcala, where the natives offered him his support to defeat the mexicas. They began to build brigs to besiege Tenochtitlán in company of more native allies, the conflict with [[Pedro de Alvarado|Pedro of Alvarado]] in the [[Tlatelolco (altepetl)|market of Tlatelolco]], the sacrifices of the Spaniards, the capture of [[Cuauhtémoc|Cuauhtemoc]], the defeat of the mexicas and the conquest Mexico-Tenochtitlán.Cortés, Hernán. ''Cartas y relaciones de Hernan Cortés al emperador Carlos V''. Edited by Pascual de Gayangos. Paris: A. Chaix, 1866. Microfilm. Disponible en: https://www.historians.org/teaching-and-learning/classroom-content/teaching-and-learning-in-the-digital-age/the-conquest-of-mexico/letters-from-hernan-cortes, Consultado el 11 de diciembre, 2015 == Publications == {| class="wikitable" style="margin-bottom: 10px;" !Translator !Printer !Language !Date !Place |- |Jacobo Cronberger | |Seville |8 November 1522 | |- |Jorge Coci | |Spanish |1523 | |- |Michel of Hochstraten | |French |1523 | |- |Pietro Savorgnani of Forli |Federico Peypus |Latin |1524 |Nuremberg |- |Pedro Martir | | |1524 | |- |Nicolás Liburnio | |Italian |1524 | |- | | |Flemish |1524 |Amberes |- |Sixto Birk and Andrés Diether | |German |1550 |Augsburg |- |Simón Grineo |

|

|1555 1616 |Basilea Rotterdam |} == References == {{Reflist}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Second relation letter from Hernan Cortes to emperor Charles V}} [[Category:Letters (message)]] [[Category:Mexican historical documents]] [[Category:Tenochtitlan]] [[Category:Tlaxcala]] [[Category:Conquistadors]] [[Category:1520 documents]]

revision.text:
{{advert|date=March 2014}} [[File:Square_Meal_Logo.jpg|128px|thumb|right|Square Meal's logo]] '''SquareMeal''' is a [[restaurant]] review and booking website and smartphone app, with reviews of 5,000 [[London]] and UK restaurants and bars.<ref>{{cite web|last=Nicholls|first=Luke|title=The A-Z of Restaurants|url=http://www.bighospitality.co.uk/Special-Features/The-A-Z-of/The-A-Z-of-Restaurants|work=Big Hospitality|accessdate=18 March 2014}}</ref><ref>http://www.macworld.co.uk/feature/iosapps/best-restaurant-apps-for-iphone-3502457/</ref>
The site publishes a yearly restaurant and bar guide<ref>{{cite web|title=Square Meal - The Guide|url=http://www.magazinesabout.co.uk/magazines/view/Square+Meal+-+The+Guide|work=Magazines about...|accessdate=18 March 2014}}</ref> and runs the BMW Restaurant of the Year Awards. The 2014 winner was Gymkhana.<ref>{{cite web|title=Gymkhana wins BMW Square Meal Restaurant of the Year award 2014|last1=McCormack|first1=Ben|url=http://www.squaremeal.co.uk/news/gymkhana-wins-bmw-square-meal-award|website=SquareMeal.co.uk|publisher=Monomax Ltd|accessdate=18 December 2014}}</ref> Previous winners have included The Five Fields in 2013,<ref>{{cite web|title=The Five Fields wins the BMW Square Meal Restaurant of the Year 2013|url=http://www.hospitalityandcateringnews.com/2014/01/the-five-fields-wins-the-bmw-square-meal-restaurant-of-the-year-2013/|work=Hospitality and Catering News|accessdate=18 March 2014}}</ref> Dabbous in 2012<ref>{{cite journal|last=Byrne|first=Jonathan|title=The Constant Eater|journal=The London & UK Datebook|date=Spring 2014|volume=19|issue=3|pages=11}}</ref> and Pollen Street Social in 2011.<ref>{{cite web|last=Girl|first=Guide|title=Jason Atherton's Pollen Street Social wins Square Meal's best restaurant award|url=http://blogs.catererandhotelkeeper.co.uk/blogs/guide-girl/square-meal/|work=Guide Girl Blog|accessdate=18 March 2014}}</ref> The award for BMW Square Meal Award for Best UK Restaurant went to Northcote.<ref>{{cite web|title=Northcote Wins 2014 BMW Square Meal Award for Best UK Restaurant|url=http://www.thestaffcanteen.com/news/northcote-wins-2014-bmw-square-meal-award-best-uk-restaurant|website=http://www.thestaffcanteen.com/|accessdate=13 January 2015}}</ref> Previous winners include Purnell's Bistro<ref>{{cite web|title=About Glynn Purnell|url=http://www.purnellsbistro-gingers.com/glynn-purnell/|website=Purnell's Bistro|accessdate=7 January 2015}}</ref> and [[The Kitchin]].<ref>{{cite web|last1=Evans|first1=Nicky|title=The Kitchin wins Square Meal BMW award for Best UK restaurant 2011|url=http://www.squaremeal.co.uk/news/the-kitchin-wins-square-meal-bmw-award-for-best-uk-restaurant-2011|website=SquareMeal.co.uk|publisher=Monomax Ltd|accessdate=13 January 2015}}</ref>
SquareMeal provides [[à la carte]] restaurant bookings in the UK, with users making reservations by telephone, email and online booking. The website lists over 11,000 bookable restaurants online,{{citation needed|date=March 2014}} in addition to restaurant news, reviews and articles. Diners can review and give restaurants a star rating whilst bloggers can link their [[blog]] reviews of restaurants. The site also runs a premium points-based Reward scheme with members receiving points when they book online. Their Concierge service, launched in 2012, allows bookers to find restaurants or venues for private dining.
SquareMeal’s holding company, Monomax Ltd, is the publisher of printed versions of the SquareMeal Restaurants & Bars Guide and Venues & Events Guide. These are free to qualifying executives in Central London and have a circulation of 104,000.<ref>{{cite web|title=Square Meal Magazine|url=http://www.magazinesabout.co.uk/magazines/view/Square+Meal+Magazine|work=Magazines about...|accessdate=18 March 2014}}</ref> Members also receive a quarterly restaurant and lifestyle magazine and e-newsletters.
==Venues & Events== SquareMeal’s Venues & Events is a guide and website that provides events professionals with information about venues and events suppliers in London and the UK.
Their annual trade show, Venues & Events Live is held in September at [[Old Billingsgate Market]]. Its 2013 show drew over 7,000 events organisers.<ref>{{cite web|title=Venues & Events Live drew 7,000|url=http://www.conference-news.co.uk/news/2013/09/25/Venues--Events-Live-drew-7000-says-Square-Meal/6263|work=Conference News|accessdate=18 March 2014}}</ref> Members of the SquareMeal venues and events audience receive a quarterly Magazine, e-newsletters and the annual Venues and Events Guide, published by Monomax Ltd. SquareMeal also runs a free helpline to assist events professionals. It handles over £5m of venue & corporate entertainment enquiries annually.{{citation needed|date=March 2014}}<ref>{{cite web|title=About Square Meal|url=http://www.squaremeal.co.uk/about|work=Square Meal|accessdate=19 March 2014}}</ref>
==History==
SquareMeal was founded in 1989 by University friends Simon White and Mark de Wesselow,<ref>{{cite web|last=Pigott|first=Sudi|title=From deals to meals|url=http://www.ft.com/cms/s/0/38a9c50c-be2b-11d9-9473-00000e2511c8.html|work=Financial Times|accessdate=18 March 2014}}</ref> whilst working in the [[City of London]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Square Meal|url=http://www.catererandhotelkeeper.co.uk/articles/28/7/2005/301866/square-meal.htm|work=Caterer and Hotelkeeper|accessdate=18 March 2014}}</ref>
==Connections==
The online restaurant booking service is powered by BookaTable (previously known as Livebookings<ref>{{cite web|title=Livebookings joins forces with Square Meal|url=http://eatoutmagazine.co.uk/livebookings-joins-forces-square-meal|work=Eat Out Magazine|accessdate=18 March 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last=Emma|first=Eversham|title=Big Hospitality|url=http://www.bighospitality.co.uk/New-Products/Livebookings-and-Square-Meal-announce-partnership|work=Livebookings and Square Meal announce partnership|accessdate=18 March 2014}}</ref>) and [[OpenTable]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Stay booked with OpenTable|url=http://www.toptable.co.uk/opentable-restaurant-management-system#/delight_diners|work=TopTable|accessdate=18 March 2014}}</ref>
The site's editor Ben McCormack is a contributor to the ''[[The Daily Telegraph|Telegraph]]'' Luxury magazine.<ref>{{cite web|title=Our Experts|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/luxury/our-experts/|work=Telegraph Luxury|accessdate=18 March 2014}}</ref>
SquareMeal supports homeless charity [[StreetSmart]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Restaurant Guide Backs Homeless Charity with Celebrity Chef Campaign|url=http://uk.prweb.com/releases/2012/11/prweb10105934.htm|work=PR Web|accessdate=18 March 2014}}</ref> The campaign is supported by [[Richard Bacon (broadcaster)|Richard Bacon]] and [[Stephen Fry]] and chefs including [[Angela Hartnett]], [[Marcus Wareing]], [[Jason Atherton]] and [[Fergus Henderson]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Helping the Homeless at Christmas|url=http://www.streetsmart.org.uk/news.php|work=StreetSmart|accessdate=19 March 2014}}</ref>
==References== {{Reflist}}
[[Category:1989 establishments in the United Kingdom]] [[Category:Restaurant guides]]

{{Use dmy dates|date=May 2016}} '''Sverigetopplistan''' ({{IPA-sv|²sværjɛˌtɔpːˌlɪstan|lang}}, lit. "Sweden top list") is the [[Sweden|Swedish]] national [[record chart]], earlier known as '''Topplistan''' (1975–1997) and '''Hitlistan''' (1998–2007) and known by its current name since October 2007, based on sales data from the [[Swedish Recording Industry Association]] (in [[Swedish language|Swedish]] Grammofonleverantörernas förening). Before Topplistan, music sales in Sweden were recorded by '''Kvällstoppen''',<ref>{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=mSkEAAAAMBAJ&pg=RA1-PA48&dq=Swedish+Kvallstoppen+chart&hl=en&sa=X&ei=OgkbUeW6IcWJlAWAvIGQBQ&ved=0CDEQ6AEwAA#v=onepage&q=Swedish%20Kvallstoppen%20chart&f=false|title=Intl Jukebox Survey|language=|date=|last=|first=|accessdate=13 February 2013|publisher=''Billboard'', 19 December 1970, p. 48}}</ref> whose weekly chart was a combined albums and singles list.
== History == For the period of 1976 to 2006, the official Swedish music charts were published by [[Sveriges Radio P3]], a station owned by [[Sveriges Radio]]. At the end of 2006, it stopped publishing the general charts, which were entrusted to [[Swedish Recording Industry Association]] in the beginning of 2007. However, Sveriges Radio P3 continued to publish the most downloaded music charts, according to the statistics compiled by Nielsen SoundScan. The new strictly-download chart was called [[DigiListan]].
Since late 2006, the chart has included legal [[Music downloading|downloads]]. On 29 October 2010 the chart became the first in the world to include [[streaming media|music streaming]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.musikindustrin.se/artikel/2064/SVERIGETOPPLISTAN_Forsaljning_av_strommad_musik_inkluderas_i_listan.html|title=Försäljning av strömmad musik inkluderas i listan|language=Swedish|date=29 October 2010|last=Nylin|first=Lars|accessdate=28 November 2010|publisher=Musikindustrin}}</ref>
From 14 November 1975 to 8 September 1993 the chart was only published every 2 weeks.
== Charts published == Until 28 October 2004, charts were published weekly on Fridays. At that date, the publication day was moved to Thursday, until end of 2008. However, the chart reverted to Fridays in January 2009 for a period of two years. Then, in January 2011, the publication day was moved to Monday.
Currently, the following charts are included: ;Albums * Albums Top 60 * Compilations Top 20 * Physical Top 20 * Vinyl Top 10 * Classical Top 10 * Hard Rock Top 20 * Jazz Top 20 * Hip-Hop Top 20 * DVDs Top 20
;Songs * Singles Top 100 <small>(replacing the Top 60 chart starting with week 3/2015 chart dated 15 January 2015)</small> * Heatseeker Top 20 * Swedish Top 20 * Dance Top 20
;Defunct * Ringtones Top 20 <small>(published until January 2012)</small>
From 1976 to 2006, the sales chart was broadcast on [[Sveriges Radio]] P3. P3 only presents sales data for digital downloads ([[DigiListan]]), tracked by [[Nielsen SoundScan]], since 2007.
== List of number one hits == * [[List of number-one singles and albums in Sweden]]
== See also == * [[DigiListan]] - ''The Official Swedish Download Chart''
== References == {{reflist}}
== External links == * [http://www.sverigetopplistan.se/ Sverigetopplistan] {{Svenska}} * [http://www.swedishcharts.com/ Swedish Charts website] (contains archives)
{{Record Charts}} {{SwedishNumber1s}}

revision.text:
'''The Newcastle Programme''' was a statement of policies passed by the representatives of the English and Welsh [[Liberal Party (UK)|Liberal Associations]] meeting at the annual conference of the [[National Liberal Federation]] (NLF) in [[Newcastle upon Tyne]] in 1891. The centrepiece of the Newcastle Programme was the primacy of [[Irish Home Rule]], but associated with it were a raft of other reforms, in particular: land reform; reform of the Lords; shorter parliaments; district and parish councils; registration reform and abolition of [[plural voting]]; [[local option|local veto]] on drink sales; employers' liability for workers' accidents and Scottish and Welsh [[disestablishment]].<ref name="answers.com">{{cite encyclopedia|title=Newcastle Programme|url=http://www.answers.com/topic/newcastle-programme|encyclopedia=A Dictionary of British History|publisher=[[Oxford University Press]]}} From [[Answers.com]].</ref><ref>{{cite book|author=Chris Cook|title=A Short History of the Liberal Party: The Road Back to Power|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Y1p9DAAAQBAJ&pg=PA25|year=2010|publisher=Palgrave Macmillan UK|pages=24–26}}</ref>
The Newcastle Programme was therefore important for two reasons; first, it gave the Liberal party a [[Radicalism (historical)|Radical]] agenda<ref>{{cite book|last=Searle|first=G. R.|authorlink=G. R. Searle|title=The Liberal Party|year=2001|publisher=[[Palgrave Macmillan]]|isbn=9780333786611|page=33}}</ref> on which to fight the next general election and second, the detailed 'shopping list' of policies it adopted was innovatory in British politics, setting a precedent for modern political parties. Today ordinary members of all major political parties participate in policy development and the parties present the electorate with a programme or manifesto for government, agreed or endorsed in some way by their members.
==Liberal campaigning== The Liberal Party's leading pioneer of organised campaigning had been [[Joseph Chamberlain]]. In 1885, he put forward the Radical Programme, unauthorised by the party leadership, as an election manifesto for using the constructive power of the state but Liberal leader [[William Ewart Gladstone]] subverted Chamberlain's efforts, co-opting the NLF for mainstream Liberalism. By adopting Home Rule for Ireland as his banner, Gladstone trumped the Radical Programme, driving Chamberlain out of the party to form the [[Liberal Unionist Party|Liberal Unionists]]. In the great schism of 1886 over Home Rule, the NLF deserted Chamberlain to remain loyal to Gladstone.<ref name="Little2006">{{cite web|last=Little|first=Tony|title=The Newcastle Programme|url=http://www.liberalhistory.org.uk/item_single.php?item_id=30&item=history|publisher=[[Liberal Democrat History Group]]|date=27 July 2006|accessdate=29 December 2008|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20061001004203/http://www.liberalhistory.org.uk/item_single.php?item_id=30&item=history|archivedate=1 October 2006|df=}}</ref>
==Home Rule== Between 1886 and 1891, Home Rule dominated Liberal policy debates but two events damaged their Irish allies. In 1887, ''[[The Times]]'' published letters, implicating [[Charles Stewart Parnell]], the Irish [[Home Rule League|Home Rule party]] leader, in the [[Phoenix Park murders]] of a government minister and a civil servant, although a high-profile government inquiry later discovered the letters to be forgeries. In 1890, the divorce of [[Katharine O'Shea]], which identified Parnell as Mrs O'Shea's lover, split the Irish party and scandalised [[nonconformist]] Liberals. The split in the Irish Home Rule party in 1890 weakened the likelihood of a successful Home Rule Bill. At the 1891 meeting of the NLF in [[Newcastle upon Tyne]] Gladstone reaffirmed the primacy of Home Rule, but associated it with reforms on the mainland by adopting various proposals of the NLF Council, in particular: land reform; reform of the Lords; shorter parliaments; district and parish councils; registration reform and abolition of [[plural voting]]; local veto on drink sales; employers' liability for workers' accidents; Scottish and Welsh [[disestablishment]].<ref name="answers.com" /> The Newcastle programme was to be the solution to these dilemmas, a manifesto for British government.
==National Liberal Federation== Each year the National Liberal Federation met for debate in what may be seen as the forerunner of today's political party conferences. The NLF developed a process by which it passed an omnibus resolution incorporating all the policies that had been agreed in debate. In the autumn of 1891, the Federation met in Newcastle upon Tyne. In addition to Home Rule, the policies, which were crowded onto the omnibus, may be divided into three main areas: rural, religious and electoral reform. On 2 October 1891, Gladstone spoke to the NLF and for the first time, a Liberal Party leader had lent support to a programme proposed by the party's grass roots.<ref>{{cite book|author=Robert Spence Watson|title=The National Liberal Federation: From Its Commencement to the General Election of 1906|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=0nRmPcRdH2gC&pg=PA130|year=1907|page=130}}</ref>
However, one historian has argued that the Radicals inside the Liberal Party lacked the leadership to ensure their programme was truly implemented. [[Michael Bentley (historian)|Michael Bentley]] suggests that while Gladstone and the Liberal leadership was obliged to listen to the opinion of such a significant section of the party, they were able to slide along without making firm commitments and to pick and choose from the 'rag-bag' of policies that made up the Newcastle Programme, prioritising those they wanted and forgetting those they disliked.<ref>{{cite book|last=Bentley|first=Michael|authorlink=Michael Bentley (historian)|title=The Climax of Liberal Politics, 1868-1916: British Liberalism in Theory and Practice|year=1987|publisher=[[Edward Arnold (publisher)|Edward Arnold]]|isbn=9780713164947|page=102}}</ref>
One of Gladstone's biographers also supports this assessment. [[Roy Jenkins]] asserts that Gladstone's only real interest now lay in Irish Home Rule, but he allowed [[John Morley]] and [[William Vernon Harcourt (politician)|William Vernon Harcourt]] to cobble together the Newcastle Programme which he describes as 'a capacious ragbag... weak on theme'. According to Jenkins, Gladstone had neither the time nor energy to oppose the NLF programme and decided to swallow it whole just to ensure the party remained wedded to Home Rule as its principal policy.<ref>{{cite book|last=Jenkins|first=Roy|authorlink=Roy Jenkins|title=Gladstone|year=1996|publisher=[[Macmillan Publishers|Papermac]]|isbn=9780333662090|page=581}}</ref>
Gladstone's endorsement of the Newcastle Programme had one important outcome. A few weeks later, on 25 November, [[Lord Hartington]], the leader of the [[Liberal Unionist Party]], announced that there was no longer any hope of re-union with the [[Gladstonian Liberalism|Gladstonian Liberals]].<ref name="Little2006" />
==The failure to implement the Newcastle Programme== The Liberal Party won the 1892 election, but its majority relied on [[Irish Parliamentary Party|Irish Nationalist]] support, and the results were far from the sort of endorsement from the electorate that Gladstone hoped.<ref>{{cite book|last=Douglas|first=Roy|title=Liberals: A History of the Liberal and Liberal Democratic Parties|year=2005|publisher=[[Continuum International Publishing Group|Hambledon and London]]|isbn=9781852853532|page=83}}</ref> The new government was unable to enact much of the Newcastle Programme, even those parts that Gladstone approved, because of implacable opposition from the [[Conservative Party (UK)|Conservative]]-dominated [[House of Lords]].
According to one historian of the Liberal Party, the Conservative leader [[Robert Gascoyne-Cecil, 3rd Marquess of Salisbury|Lord Salisbury]] justified their rejection of the Liberal measures including, crucially, Home Rule, on the basis that the Liberal victory in 1892 had rested on the votes of 150 electors in eight constituencies collected by offering many different policy bribes.<ref>{{cite book|last=Parry|first=Jonathan|title=The Rise and Fall of Liberal Government in Victorian Britain|year=1993|publisher=[[Yale University Press]]|isbn=9780300057799|page=309}}</ref> Of the Newcastle Programme, the government's principal achievements were [[employers' liability]], [[parish councils in England|parish councils]] and [[William Vernon Harcourt (politician)|William Vernon Harcourt]]'s 1894 budget, which introduced graduated [[death duties]].
Gladstone resigned as [[prime minister]] in 1894 and was replaced with [[Archibald Primrose, 5th Earl of Rosebery|Lord Rosebery]] who poured scorn on the Newcastle Programme as the 'flyblown phylacteries of obsolete policies'.<ref>Douglas 2005, p. 106.</ref> When the government's efforts to bring in temperance reform and Welsh disestablishment also failed, Rosebery's disunited cabinet were almost anxious for an excuse to resign.<ref name="Little2006" />
The Conservatives won the [[United Kingdom general election, 1895|1895 general election]] ushering in ten years of Tory government. The Radical policy inheritance of the Newcastle Programme would have to wait for the reforming governments of [[Henry Campbell-Bannerman]] and [[H. H. Asquith]] before being cashed in.
==See also== *[[Francis Schnadhorst]] * [[History of the United Kingdom]]
==References== {{Reflist}} ==Further reading== * Fahey, David M. "Rosebery,‘The Times’ and the Newcastle Programme." ''Historical Research'' 45.111 (1972): 135-142.
{{DEFAULTSORT:Newcastle Programme, The}} [[Category:Liberal Party (UK)]] [[Category:Political manifestos]] [[Category:Political history of the United Kingdom]] [[Category:1891 in politics]] [[Category:1891 in the United Kingdom]] [[Category:Party programs]] [[Category:1891 documents]]
